question.title: Debugging core Maven from IntelliJ IDEA
question.body:
Using IntelliJ IDEA, I would like to debug some of the core Maven code when executing my build.

For this to happen, I need to be able to browse the source code of those Maven Plugins that are used by my project and be able to set a breakpoint in that. Let's - for the sake of the example - say that I want break inside some code in the Maven Surefire plugin.

I have no idea how to to locate this source code in IntelliJ IDEA? Sure, IDEA provides features for downloading sources for the libs used by the application. But I cannot see that it provides features for downloading sources for the Maven plugins used by the build.

Once I've accomplished the whole setting the breakpoint exercise (which clearly may involve getting the IDE to download the code, allowing the IDE to let me browse the code, etc) I actually know how to execute a Maven goal with a debugger attached. So my question is not about that.

answers.body:
Follow these steps:

1. Determine the version of the plugin used by your project

For Surefire plugin, you can simply observe the mvn test output.

[INFO] --- surefire:3.2.5:test (default-test) @ my-project ---

Even better, use mvn help:effective-pom

<plugin>
  <artifactId>maven-surefire-plugin</artifactId>
  <version>3.2.5</version>
  <executions>
    <execution>
      <id>default-test</id>
      <phase>test</phase>
      <goals>
        <goal>test</goal>
      </goals>
    </execution>
  </executions>
</plugin>

2. Pull in the plugin as a dependency in your project.

The version must precisely match one determined above

<dependency>
    <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-surefire-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>3.2.5</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>

3. You can now inspect code, download sources, etc

In your case, AbstractSurefireMojo.execute is a good place to start

4. To debug, in your Maven window use:

my-project -> Lifecycle -> test (or another phase) -> Right Mouse Button -> Debug

79693412.body: I dont expect you to add it permanently and merge it to master. Make this change locally or on a dedicated branch, and remove it after you are done with debugging.

Hmm. While I admit that this will possibly work I hesitate to add a dependency to my project (even if scope is test) for the sole reason that I want to debug something. I'm concerned that my colleagues will wonder why this dependency exists, in case I forget to remove it again. For now I give you an upvote for a thoughtful answer !!
